a.g: O mankind, fear your Lord, who created you from one soul and created from it its mate and dispersed from both of them many men and women. And fear Allah, through whom you ask one another, and the wombs. Indeed Allah is ever, over you, an Observer.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j4 k08
Indeed, God the Exalted has said: "Indeed, God has ever been, over you, a Watcher [raqīb]." The second station [marābiṭah]: The Vigilant Self-Observation [murāqabah]. When a person has instructed his soul [nafs] and stipulated upon it what we have mentioned, nothing remains but the vigilant self-observation [murāqabah] of it when plunging into actions, and observing it with the watchful eye. For if it is left, it becomes insolent and corrupt. Let us mention the virtue of vigilant self-observation [murāqabah], then its degrees. As for the virtue: Gabriel, peace be upon him, asked about spiritual excellence [iḥsān]. He said: "That you worship God as if you see Him." A hadith agreed upon from the narration of Abu Hurairah, and Muslim narrated it from the narration of 'Umar, and it has preceded. And He, peace be upon him, said: "Worship God as if you see Him, for if you do not see Him, indeed He sees you." The hadith "Worship God as if you see Him" has preceded. And He the Exalted has said: "Then is He who is a maintainer [qā'im] over every soul [nafs] for what it has earned...?" And He the Exalted has said: "Does he not know that indeed God sees?" And God the Exalted has said: "Indeed, God has ever been, over you, a Watcher [raqīb]."

a.g: And give to the orphans their properties and do not substitute the defective [of your own] for the good [of theirs]. And do not consume their properties into your own. Indeed, that is ever a great sin.

And if you fear that you will not deal justly with the orphan girls, then marry those that please you of [other] women, two or three or four. But if you fear that you will not be just, then [marry only] one or those your right hand possesses. That is more suitable that you may not incline [to injustice].
And give the women [upon marriage] their [bridal] gifts graciously. But if they give up willingly to you anything of it, then take it in satisfaction and ease.

Vol3 book 10a
And another group, their delusion [ghurur] became great in the art of jurisprudence [fiqh], so they imagined that the ruling [hukm] of the servant between him and God follows his ruling in the court of judgment. So they devised stratagems [hila] to repel rightful claims, and they misinterpreted weighty expressions, and were deluded by outward appearances [zawahir] and erred in them. This is from the category of error in legal verdicts [fatwa] and delusion therein, and error in verdicts is something that is frequent. But this type has become widespread among the masses except the discerning [akyaas] among them, so we point to examples: From that is their verdict that whenever a woman absolves [abara'at] from the dowry [sadaq], the husband is absolved between him and God, the Exalted. And that is an error. Rather, the husband may mistreat the wife such that he constricts her affairs with bad character, so she is compelled to seek deliverance, so she absolves the husband to be free of him. So it is an absolution [ibra'] not from a contented self [nafs]. And He, the Exalted, has said: "But if they, of their own good pleasure, remit any part of it to you, take it and enjoy it with right good cheer." And contentment of the self [tayyibat al-nafs] is other than contentment of the heart [qalb]. For a person may will with his heart what his self is not content with, for he wills cupping with his heart but his self dislikes it. And contentment of the self is only that her self permits the absolution, not from a necessity that confronts her, such that when she is placed between two harms, she chooses the lesser of them. This is, in truth, seizure [musadara] with inner compulsion [ikrah al-batin]. Yes, the judge [qadi] in this world [dunya] does not perceive the hearts and the intentions, so he looks to the outward absolution and that she was not coeraked by an outward cause, and inner compulsion is not something creation perceives. But whenever the Greatest Judge [al-Qadi al-Akbar] undertakes judgment on the plain of resurrection [qiyama], this will not be counted nor considered in establishing the absolution. And for that reason, it is not permissible to take a person's wealth except from a contented self of his. So if wealth were demanded from a person in front of people, and he felt ashamed before the people not to give it, and he wished the request had been in private so he would not give it, but he feared the pain of people's blame and he feared the pain of surrendering the wealth, and he weighed his soul [nafs] between them and chose the lesser of the two pains, which is the pain of surrender, and so he surrendered it—there is no difference between this and seizure. For the meaning of seizure is inflicting pain on the body with the whip until that becomes stronger than the pain of the heart in parting with wealth, so he chooses the lesser of the two pains. And the request in a situation of shame and ostentation is a strike upon the heart with a whip. And there is no difference between striking the inner [batin] and striking the outer [zahir] before God, the Exalted, for the inner before God, the Exalted, is outer. It is only the judge of this world who rules by the apparent [zahir] of his statement "I have given it," because he cannot ascertain what is in the heart. Likewise, whoever gives for fear of the evil of his tongue or the evil of his slander, it is forbidden [haram] for him. And likewise, every wealth taken in this manner is forbidden. Do you not see what came in the story of David, peace be upon him, when he said—after he was forgiven—"O Lord, how shall I deal with my adversary?" So he was commanded to seek lawful release [istihlal] from him, and he was dead, so he was commanded to call him in the rock of the Sacred House. So he called: "O Uriah!" He answered him: "At your service, O Prophet of God. You brought me out from Paradise, what do you want?" He said: "I wronged you in a matter, so forgive it for me." He said: "I have done that, O Prophet of God." So he departed, having relied upon that. Then Gabriel, peace be upon him, said to him: "Did you mention to him what you did?" He said: "Did I not forgive it for you?" He said: "Will you not ask me what that sin was?" He said: "What is it, O Prophet of God?" He said: "Such and such," and he mentioned the affair of the woman, and the answer was cut off. So he said, "O Uriah, will you not answer me?" He said: "O Prophet of God, this is not how the Prophets act, until I stand with you before God." So David turned to weeping and wailing from the head until God promised him that He would ask it from him for him in the Hereafter [Akhira]. Thus, this alerts you that a gift [hiba] not from a contented heart [qalb] is of no benefit, and that contentment of the heart is not attained except through knowledge [ma'rifa]. So likewise, contentment of the heart does not occur in absolution, gift, and other matters except when a person is left to his own choice [ikhtiyar], until the motives [dawa'i] emanate from his very soul [nafs], not that his motives are compelled to act by stratagems and coercion.

a.g: And do not give the weak-minded your property, which Allah has made a means of sustenance for you, but provide for them with it and clothe them and speak to them words of appropriate kindness.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 1
And Jesus, peace be upon him, said: Do not hang jewels [jawāhir] around the necks of swine, for wisdom [ḥikma] is better than a jewel, and whoever dislikes it is worse than swine. And for this reason it is said: Give to every servant according to the measure of his intellect [‘aql], and weigh for him with the scale of his understanding [fahm] so that you may be safe from him and he may benefit from you, otherwise denial will occur due to the disparity of the measure. And one of the scholars was asked about something and he did not answer, so the questioner said: Have you not heard the Messenger of God, may God bless him and grant him peace, say: "Whoever conceals beneficial knowledge will come on the Day of Resurrection bridled with a bridle of fire"? So he said: Leave the bridle and go, for if one comes who comprehends [yafqahu] and I conceal it from him, then let him bridle me. For God, the Exalted, has said: "And do not give the foolish [sufahā’] your wealth" [4:5] as an indication that safeguarding knowledge from one who would corrupt it and harm himself is more paramount. And the injustice [ẓulm] in giving to one who is undeserving is not less than the injustice in withholding from one who is deserving. Shall I scatter pearls among a grazing herd of cattle, only to find them stored away by the shepherd of the sheep? For they, in their ignorance [jahl] of its worth, have passed the night, so I will not spend the morning adorning cattle with it. If the Gentle [laṭīf] God, in His gentleness [luṭf], is gracious, and I encounter people fit for the sciences [‘ulūm] and the wisdom [ḥikam], I will disseminate what is beneficial and gain a legacy; otherwise, it remains stored with me and concealed. For whoever bestows knowledge [‘ilm] upon the ignorant [juhhāl] squanders it, and whoever withholds it from those who are deserving has indeed been unjust [ẓalama].

a.g: And test the orphans [in their abilities] until they reach marriageable age. Then if you perceive in them sound judgement, release their property to them. And do not consume it excessively and quickly, [anticipating] that they will grow up. And whoever, [when acting as guardian], is self-sufficient should refrain [from taking a fee]; and whoever is poor - let him take according to what is acceptable. Then when you release their property to them, bring witnesses upon them. And sufficient is Allah as Accountant.
For men is a share of what the parents and close relatives leave, and for women is a share of what the parents and close relatives leave, be it little or much - an obligatory share.
And when [other] relatives and orphans and the needy are present at the [time of] division, then provide for them [something] out of the estate and speak to them words of appropriate kindness.
And let those [executors and guardians] fear [injustice] as if they [themselves] had left weak offspring behind and feared for them. So let them fear Allah and speak words of appropriate justice.
Indeed, those who devour the property of orphans unjustly are only consuming into their bellies fire. And they will be burned in a Blaze.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k04
Indeed, those who consume the wealth of the orphans [yataama] unjustly [zulman], they only consume fire [naaran] into their bellies, and they will enter the Blaze [sa'ira].

a.g: Allah instructs you concerning your children: for the male, what is equal to the share of two females. But if there are [only] daughters, two or more, for them is two thirds of one's estate. And if there is only one, for her is half. And for one's parents, to each one of them is a sixth of his estate if he left children. But if he had no children and the parents [alone] inherit from him, then for his mother is one third. And if he had brothers [or sisters], for his mother is a sixth, after any bequest he [may have] made or debt. Your parents or your children - you know not which of them are nearest to you in benefit. [These shares are] an obligation [imposed] by Allah. Indeed, Allah is ever Knowing and Wise.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k08
Indeed, whoever is overcome by grief [huzn] or longing [shawq] or regret [nadam]—how can his state be suited by the words of the Almighty: "God instructs you concerning your children: for the male the share of two females..."? Yes, whoever is overcome by a dominant, all-consuming state [hala] that leaves no room for anything else, and who possesses, with it, a wakefulness [yaqaza] and a penetrating, acute intelligence [dhaka'] by which he perceives the distant meanings [ma'ani] within the words—his spiritual passion [wajd] may be stirred by everything he hears. Like one for whom, upon hearing the words of the Almighty "God instructs you concerning your children," the state [hala] of death arises—the death that necessitates the will—and that every person must inevitably leave behind his wealth and his children, and they are his two beloved things from the world [dunya], so he leaves one beloved for the other and abandons them both. Thus, fear [khawf] and anguish [jaza'] overcome him. Or he hears the mention of God in His words "God instructs you concerning your children," and he is awestruck by the Name alone, oblivious to what precedes and follows it. Or the mercy [rahma] of God upon His servants and His compassion occur to him—that He Himself undertook the division of their inheritances, providing for them in their life and their death—so he says, "If He looks after our children after our death, then we have no doubt that He looks after us." Then a state of hope [raja'] is stirred within him, and that bequeaths to him gladness [istibshar] and joy [surur]. Or it occurs to him from the words of the Almighty "for the male the share of two females" the preference [tafdil] of the male for being a man over the female, and that the virtue [fadl] in the Hereafter [akhira] is for men whom no commerce nor sale distracts from the remembrance of God, and that whoever is distracted by other than God from God, he is from the females, not from the men, in truth [tahqiq]. So he fears that he may be veiled [hujiba] or delayed in the bliss [na'im] of the Hereafter as the female was delayed in the worldly [dunya] wealth. So the likes of this may stir spiritual passion [wajd]. But only for one in whom are two qualities: the first, an all-consuming, overwhelming, dominant state [hala]; and the second, a profound perception [tafattun] and a complete, intense wakefulness [yaqaza] for being alerted by proximate matters to distant meanings [ma'ani].

a.g: And for you is half of what your wives leave if they have no child. But if they have a child, for you is one fourth of what they leave, after any bequest they [may have] made or debt. And for the wives is one fourth if you leave no child. But if you leave a child, then for them is an eighth of what you leave, after any bequest you [may have] made or debt. And if a man or woman leaves neither ascendants nor descendants but has a brother or a sister, then for each one of them is a sixth. But if they are more than two, they share a third, after any bequest which was made or debt, as long as there is no detriment [caused]. [This is] an ordinance from Allah, and Allah is Knowing and Forbearing.

These are the limits [set by] Allah, and whoever obeys Allah and His Messenger will be admitted by Him to gardens [in Paradise] under which rivers flow, abiding eternally therein; and that is the great attainment.
And whoever disobeys Allah and His Messenger and transgresses His limits - He will put him into the Fire to abide eternally therein, and he will have a humiliating punishment.

Those who commit unlawful sexual intercourse of your women - bring against them four [witnesses] from among you. And if they testify, confine the guilty women to houses until death takes them or Allah ordains for them [another] way.
And the two who commit it among you, dishonor them both. But if they repent and correct themselves, leave them alone. Indeed, Allah is ever Accepting of repentance and Merciful.

The repentance accepted by Allah is only for those who do wrong in ignorance [or carelessness] and then repent soon after. It is those to whom Allah will turn in forgiveness, and Allah is ever Knowing and Wise.

But repentance is not [accepted] of those who [continue to] do evil deeds up until, when death comes to one of them, he says, "Indeed, I have repented now," or of those who die while they are disbelievers. For them We have prepared a painful punishment.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book10
Indeed, Mujahid said regarding His, the Exalted's, statement: "And repentance is not for those who commit evil deeds until, when death approaches one of them, he says, 'Indeed, I have repented now,'" he said: When he witnesses the angels [al-mala'ikah], then at that moment the countenance of the Angel of Death [Malak al-Mawt] becomes apparent to him, so do not ask about the taste of the bitterness of death [mawt] and its distress at the succession of its agonies. And for that reason, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, used to say: "O God, make easy for Muhammad the agonies of death [sakarat al-mawt]."

a.g: O you who have believed, it is not lawful for you to inherit women by compulsion. And do not make difficulties for them in order to take [back] part of what you gave them unless they commit a clear immorality. And live with them in kindness. For if you dislike them - perhaps you dislike a thing and Allah makes therein much good.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k02
Indeed, the second refinement [adab] is to maintain excellent character [husn al-khuluq] with them, and to bear patiently the harm [adha] that comes from them, out of compassion for them, due to the deficiency of their intellect [aql]. And Allah, the Exalted, has said: "And live with them in kindness [ma'ruf]." And He said, in magnifying their right [haqq]: "And they have taken from you a solemn covenant [mithaq ghaliz]." And He said: "And the companion [sahib] at your side." It is said this refers to the woman. And the final words the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, counseled—three matters he would speak until his tongue grew heavy and his speech became faint—he would say: "The prayer [as-salah], the prayer [as-salah]. And those whom your right hands possess [ma malakat aymanukum]—do not burden them with what they cannot bear. Allah, Allah, concerning women [nisaa'], for indeed they are captives [awan] in your hands." Meaning, they are captives; you have taken them by the trust [amanah] of Allah, and you have made lawful their private parts by the word [kalimah] of Allah.

a.g: But if you want to replace one wife with another and you have given one of them a great amount [in gifts], do not take [back] from it anything. Would you take it in injustice and manifest sin?
And how could you take it while you have gone in unto each other and they have taken from you a solemn covenant?
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k02
Indeed, and He said in magnifying their right: "And they have taken from you a solemn covenant [mīthāqan ghalīẓan]." And He said: "And the companion by your side [al-ṣāḥib bil-janb]." It is said: she is the woman. And the last thing the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, enjoined—three matters he would speak of until his tongue faltered and his speech grew faint—he would say: "The prayer [al-ṣalāh], the prayer [al-ṣalāh], and those whom your right hands possess [mā malakat aymānukum]. Do not burden them with what they cannot bear. God, God, concerning them, for they are captives [ʿawān] in your hands"—meaning captives, you have taken them by the trust [amānah] of God, and you have made lawful their private parts [furūjahunna] by the word [kalimah] of God.

a.g: And do not marry those [women] whom your fathers married, except what has already occurred. Indeed, it was an immorality and hateful [to Allah] and was evil as a way.

Prohibited to you [for marriage] are your mothers, your daughters, your sisters, your father's sisters, your mother's sisters, your brother's daughters, your sister's daughters, your [milk] mothers who nursed you, your sisters through nursing, your wives' mothers, and your step-daughters under your guardianship [born] of your wives unto whom you have gone in. But if you have not gone in unto them, there is no sin upon you. And [also prohibited are] the wives of your sons who are from your [own] loins, and that you take [in marriage] two sisters simultaneously, except for what has already occurred. Indeed, Allah is ever Forgiving and Merciful.

And [also prohibited to you are all] married women except those your right hands possess. [This is] the decree of Allah upon you. And lawful to you are [all others] beyond these, [provided] that you seek them [in marriage] with [gifts from] your property, desiring chastity, not unlawful sexual intercourse. So for whatever you enjoy [of marriage] from them, give them their due compensation as an obligation. And there is no blame upon you for what you mutually agree to beyond the obligation. Indeed, Allah is ever Knowing and Wise.

And whoever among you cannot [find] the means to marry free, believing women, then [he may marry] from those whom your right hands possess of believing slave girls. And Allah is most knowing about your faith. You [believers] are of one another. So marry them with the permission of their people and give them their due compensation according to what is acceptable. [They should be] chaste, neither [of] those who commit unlawful intercourse randomly nor those who take [secret] lovers. But once they are sheltered in marriage, if they should commit adultery, then for them is half the punishment for free [unmarried] women. This [allowance] is for him among you who fears sin, but to be patient is better for you. And Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k02
Indeed, the profligate woman [al-'ahirah al-fasiqah] who is known for a paramour [khalil] and a secret lover [khaddan]—she is the one of whom Allah, the Exalted, said: "Nor those who take secret lovers [akhdan]."

a.g: Allah wants to make clear to you [the lawful from the unlawful] and guide you to the [good] practices of those before you and to accept your repentance. And Allah is Knowing and Wise.
Allah wants to accept your repentance, but those who follow [their] passions want you to digress [into] a great deviation.
And Allah wants to lighten for you [your difficulties]; and mankind was created weak.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k02
Indeed, concerning the meaning of His, the Exalted's, statement, "And man was created weak [da'if]," 'Ikrimah and Mujahid said it means he cannot be patient regarding women. And this matter, while it is suitable to be an impetus for both lives [al-hayatayn] as preceded, is the strongest instrument [ala] of Satan [al-shaytan] against the children of Adam. And to this He, peace and blessings be upon him, alluded with his saying, "I have not seen from those deficient in intellect [aql] and religion [din] more overwhelming for possessors of sound minds than you." And that is only due to the raging of desire [shahwah]. And this is a dominant affliction [baliah]; when it rages, neither intellect [aql] nor religion [din] can resist it.

a.g: O you who have believed, do not consume one another's wealth unjustly but only [in lawful] business by mutual consent. And do not kill yourselves [or one another]. Indeed, Allah is to you ever Merciful.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k01
Indeed, God the Exalted has commanded the consumption of what is good [tayyib], which is the lawful [halal]. And He placed the prohibition against consuming by falsehood [batil] before [the prohibition of] killing, to magnify the matter of the unlawful [haram] and to exalt the blessing [barakah] of the lawful [halal]. Thus He, the Exalted, said: "O you who have believed, do not consume one another's wealth unjustly [batil]..." up to His saying: "...and do not kill yourselves..." The foundational principle [asl] regarding sustenance [ta'am] is that it be good [tayyib], and this is among the obligations [fara'id] and the foundations [usul] of the religion [din].

a.g: And whoever does that in aggression and injustice - then We will drive him into a Fire. And that, for Allah, is [always] easy.
If you avoid the major sins which you are forbidden, We will remove from you your lesser sins and admit you to a noble entrance [into Paradise].

And do not wish for that by which Allah has made some of you exceed others. For men is a share of what they have earned, and for women is a share of what they have earned. And ask Allah of his bounty. Indeed Allah is ever, of all things, Knowing.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book5a
And naming this rank [al-rutbah] as envy [hasad] is a permissible and broad usage, but it is blameworthy due to His, the Exalted's, saying: 'And do not wish for that by which Allah has favored some of you over others.' So wishing for the like of that is not blameworthy, but as for wishing for that very thing itself, it is blameworthy.

a.g: And for all, We have made heirs to what is left by parents and relatives. And to those whom your oaths have bound [to you] - give them their share. Indeed Allah is ever, over all things, a Witness.

Men are in charge of women by [right of] what Allah has given one over the other and what they spend [for maintenance] from their wealth. So righteous women are devoutly obedient, guarding in [the husband's] absence what Allah would have them guard. But those [wives] from whom you fear arrogance - [first] advise them; [then if they persist], forsake them in bed; and [finally], strike them. But if they obey you [once more], seek no means against them. Indeed, Allah is ever Exalted and Grand.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k02
The fourth is that he should not expand in jest [dahik] and good character [husn al-khuluq] and agreement by following her whim [hawa] to the point that it corrupts her character and causes his awe [hayba] before her to fall away completely. Rather, he should observe moderation [i'tidal] in it. So he does not abandon awe and sternness whenever he sees a wrong [munkar], nor does he open the door to assisting in wrongs at all. Rather, whenever he sees what contradicts the Sacred Law [shar'] and manly virtue [muru'a], he should show displeasure and be vexed. Al-Hasan said, "By God, no man obeys his wife in what she desires [hawa] except that God casts him into the Fire." And 'Umar, may God be pleased with him, said, "Oppose women, for in opposing them is blessing [baraka]." And it has been said, "Consult them and oppose them." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said, "Wretched is the slave of the wife." He only said that because if he obeys her in her whim [hawa], then he is her slave, and he is wretched. For God made him the master [malik] of the woman, but he made her the master of himself. So he has reversed the matter and overturned the case, and he has obeyed Satan when he said, "And I will command them so they will change the creation of God." For the right of the man is to be followed, not a follower. And God has named men "maintainers [qawwamun] over women," and He named the husband a master [sayyid], as He, the Exalted, said, "And they found her master [sayyidaha] at the door." a.g: Worship Allah and associate nothing with Him, and to parents do good, and to relatives, orphans, the needy, the near neighbor, the neighbor farther away, the companion at your side, the traveler, and those whom your right hands possess. And the companion by your side [wa al-sahib bi al-janb]. It is said: she is the woman. And the last of what the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, enjoined were three things he would speak of until his tongue faltered and his speech became faint. a.g: Who are stingy and enjoin upon [other] people stinginess and conceal what Allah has given them of His bounty - and We have prepared for the disbelievers a humiliating punishment -
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 5
Indeed, the exposition of the censure of miserliness [bukhul]. Allah the Exalted says: "And whoever is protected from the stinginess [shuhh] of his soul [nafs]—it is those who are the successful." And He the Exalted says: "And let not those who are stingy [yabkhaluna] with what Allah has given them of His bounty think it is good for them. Rather, it is bad for them. They will be made to wear what they were stingy with as a collar on the Day of Resurrection." And He the Exalted says: "Those who are stingy [yabkhaluna] and enjoin people to stinginess [bukhl] and conceal what Allah has given them of His bounty." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Beware of stinginess [shuhh], for it destroyed those before you. It compelled them to shed their blood and deem their prohibitions lawful." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Beware of stinginess [shuhh], for it called those before you, so they shed their blood, and it called them, so they deemed their prohibitions lawful, and it called them, so they severed their ties of kinship." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The miser [bakhil], nor the deceitful, nor the traitor, especially the one of bad character, will not enter Paradise." And in a narration: "nor the tyrant." And in a narration: "nor the one who reminds of his favor." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Three destructive things: obeyed stinginess [shuhh], a followed desire [hawa], and a man's admiration of himself." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah hates three: the old fornicator, the miser [bakhil] who reminds of his favor, and the poor man who is arrogant." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The likeness of the spender and the miser [bakhil] is like two men upon whom are iron shirts from their chests to their collarbones. As for the spender, he does not spend anything except that it flows over or becomes ample upon his skin until it conceals his fingertips. As for the miser [bakhil], he does not intend to spend anything except that it shrinks and clings to every ring of his throat until it takes hold of his collarbones, so he loosens it but it does not expand." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Two traits do not gather in a believer: miserliness [bukhul] and bad character." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "O Allah, I seek refuge in You from miserliness [bukhul], and I seek refuge in You from cowardice, and I seek refuge in You from being returned to the most abject age." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Beware of oppression, for oppression is darknesses on the Day of Resurrection. And beware of obscenity, for Allah does not love the obscene nor the one who acts obscenely. And beware of stinginess [shuhh], for it only destroyed those before you. Stinginess [shuhh] commanded them to lie, so they lied, and it commanded them to oppress, so they oppressed, and it commanded them to sever ties, so they severed." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The worst thing in a man is destructive stinginess [shuhh hal'] and stripping cowardice." And a martyr was killed during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, so a weeping woman wept for him and said, "O my martyr!" So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "And what makes you know that he is a martyr? Perhaps he used to speak about what does not concern him or was stingy [yabkhalu] with what would not diminish him." And Jubayr ibn Mut'im said: While we were traveling with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and the people were with him returning from Khaybar, the Bedouins clung to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, asking him, until they pushed him to a thorny tree and snatched his cloak. So he, peace and blessings be upon him, stood and said: "Give me my cloak. For by the One in Whose Hand is my soul [nafs], if I had livestock equal to the number of these thorns, I would distribute it among you. Then you would not find me to be a miser [bakhilan], nor a liar, nor a coward."

a.g: And [also] those who spend of their wealth to be seen by the people and believe not in Allah nor in the Last Day. And he to whom Satan is a companion - then evil is he as a companion.
And what [harm would come] upon them if they believed in Allah and the Last Day and spent out of what Allah provided for them? And Allah is ever, about them, Knowing.
Indeed, Allah does not do injustice, [even] as much as an atom's weight; while if there is a good deed, He multiplies it and gives from Himself a great reward.

a.g: That Day, those who disbelieved and disobeyed the Messenger will wish they could be covered by the earth. And they will not conceal from Allah a [single] statement.

O you who have believed, do not approach prayer while you are intoxicated until you know what you are saying or in a state of janabah, except those passing through [a place of prayer], until you have washed [your whole body]. And if you are ill or on a journey or one of you comes from the place of relieving himself or you have contacted women and find no water, then seek clean earth and wipe over your faces and your hands [with it]. Indeed, Allah is ever Pardoning and Forgiving.
Have you not seen those who were given a portion of the Scripture, purchasing error [in exchange for it] and wishing you would lose the way?
And Allah is most knowing of your enemies; and sufficient is Allah as an ally, and sufficient is Allah as a helper.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book6
And when God loves him, He takes charge of him [tawalla] and grants him victory over his enemies. Indeed, his enemy is his own soul [nafs] and his base desires [shahawat]. Therefore, God does not abandon him, nor does He leave him to his own caprice [hawa] and desires [shahawat]. And for this reason, the Most High has said: "And God knows best who your enemies are, and sufficient is God as a Guardian [wali], and sufficient is God as a Helper [nasir]."

a.g: Among the Jews are those who distort words from their [proper] usages and say, "We hear and disobey" and "Hear but be not heard" and "Ra'ina," twisting their tongues and defaming the religion. And if they had said [instead], "We hear and obey" and "Wait for us [to understand]," it would have been better for them and more suitable. But Allah has cursed them for their disbelief, so they believe not, except for a few.

O you who were given the Scripture, believe in what We have sent down [to Muhammad], confirming that which is with you, before We obliterate faces and turn them toward their backs or curse them as We cursed the sabbath-breakers. And ever is the decree of Allah accomplished.
Indeed, Allah does not forgive association with Him, but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills. And he who associates others with Allah has certainly fabricated a tremendous sin.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book10
Indeed, Allah the Exalted has said: **"Indeed, Allah does not forgive association with Him [shirk], but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills."** [Chapter on the Vastness of Allah's Mercy] We conclude the book with a chapter on the vastness of the mercy [rahma] of Allah the Exalted, as an act of optimism [tafa'ul] in that, for indeed (the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, loved good omens), and we have no deeds by which we may hope for forgiveness, so we follow the example of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in optimism and we hope that He seals our end with good in this world [dunya] and the Hereafter, just as we concluded the book by mentioning His mercy [rahma]. For indeed Allah the Exalted has said: **"Indeed, Allah does not forgive association with Him [shirk], but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills."** And He the Exalted said: **"Say, 'O My servants who have transgressed against themselves [by sinning], do not despair of the mercy [rahma] of Allah. Indeed, Allah forgives all sins. Indeed, it is He who is the Forgiving, the Merciful.'"** And He the Exalted said: **"And whoever does an evil or wrongs himself then seeks forgiveness of Allah will find Allah Forgiving and Merciful."** And we seek forgiveness [istighfar] from Allah the Exalted for every slip of the foot or transgression of the pen in this book of ours and in all our books. And we seek His forgiveness for our words which our actions do not match. And we seek His forgiveness for what we claimed and displayed of knowledge [ilm] and insight [basira] into the religion of Allah the Exalted while being deficient in it. And we seek His forgiveness for every knowledge [ilm] and deed we intended for His Noble Countenance, then something else became mixed with it. And we seek His forgiveness for every promise we made to ourselves, then fell short in fulfilling. And we seek His forgiveness for every blessing [ni'ma] He bestowed upon us, then we employed it in disobedience to Him. And we seek His forgiveness for every explicit and implicit mention of the deficiency of a deficient one or the shortcoming of one who fell short, with which we were characterized. And we seek His forgiveness for every fleeting thought that called us to affectation and pretense, to adorn ourselves before people in a book we penned, or speech we composed, or knowledge [ilm] we imparted or received. And we hope, after seeking forgiveness for all of that—for us and for whoever reads this book of ours or writes it or hears it—that we are honored with forgiveness [maghfira] and mercy [rahma] and pardon for all sins, outward and inward. For generosity is immense, mercy [rahma] is vast, and bounty upon all kinds of creation is overflowing. And we are a creation from the creation of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic; we have no means to Him except His favor and His generosity. For indeed the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: **(Indeed, Allah the Exalted has one hundred mercies [rahma]; He sent down from them a single mercy [rahma] between the jinn, mankind, birds, beasts, and creeping things. Through it they show affection and through it they show mercy to one another. And He withheld ninety-nine mercies [rahma] by which He will show mercy to His servants on the Day of Resurrection.)** And it is narrated that **(When the Day of Resurrection comes, Allah the Exalted will bring out a book from beneath the Throne, in it is: 'Indeed My mercy [rahma] has preceded My wrath, and I am the Most Merciful of the merciful.' Then He will bring out of the Fire the like of the people of Paradise.)** And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: **(Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, will appear to us on the Day of Resurrection smiling, and He will say: 'Receive glad tidings, O community of Muslims, for there is not one of you except that I have placed in the Fire in his place a Jew or a Christian.')**

a.g: Have you not seen those who claim themselves to be pure? Rather, Allah purifies whom He wills, and injustice is not done to them, [even] as much as a thread [inside a date seed].

Vol1 book 2
Indeed, the first aspect [al-wajh al-awwal], which does not rely on confronting doubt, is the precaution [al-ihtiraz] from certainty [al-jazm] for fear of what it contains of self-praise [tazkiyat al-nafs]. Allah, the Exalted, says: "So do not claim purity for yourselves [fa la tuzakku anfusakum]" (4:49). And He says: "Have you not seen those who claim purity for themselves [alladhina yuzakkuuna anfusahum]?" (4:49). And the Exalted says: "See how they invent lies about Allah" (4:50). And it was said to a wise man, "What is ugly truthfulness [al-sidq al-qabih]?" He said, "A person's praise of himself." And faith [al-iman] is among the highest attributes of glory [al-majd], and certainty [al-jazm] is absolute self-praise [tazkiyah mutlaqah]. And the formula of exception [sighat al-istithna'] is as if it is a burden for one who knows self-praise [al-tazkiyah]; just as it is said to a person, "You are a doctor, or a jurist, or an exegete," and he says, "Yes, if Allah wills [in sha' Allah]," not in the manner of casting doubt [al-tashkik] but to remove himself from praising himself. Thus, the formula is the formula of hesitation [al-taraddud] and weakening [al-tad'if] of the report itself, and its meaning is the necessary weakening [al-tad'if al-lazim] from the necessary concomitants [lawazim] of the report, which is self-praise [al-tazkiyah]. And by this interpretation [ta'wil], if one were asked about a description of blame [wasf dham], it would not be proper to make an exception.

Have you not seen those who were given a portion of the Scripture, who believe in superstition and false objects of worship and say about the disbelievers, "These are better guided than the believers as to the way"?
Those are the ones whom Allah has cursed; and he whom Allah curses - never will you find for him a helper.
Or have they a share of dominion? Then [if that were so], they would not give the people [even as much as] the speck on a date seed.
Or do they envy people for what Allah has given them of His bounty? But we had already given the family of Abraham the Scripture and wisdom and conferred upon them a great kingdom.

a.g: And some among them believed in it, and some among them were averse to it. And sufficient is Hell as a blaze.

Indeed, those who disbelieve in Our verses - We will drive them into a Fire. Every time their skins are roasted through We will replace them with other skins so they may taste the punishment. Indeed, Allah is ever Exalted in Might and Wise.

a.g: O you who have believed, obey Allah and obey the Messenger and those in authority among you. And if you disagree over anything, refer it to Allah and the Messenger, if you should believe in Allah and the Last Day. That is the best [way] and best in result.

Have you not seen those who claim to have believed in what was revealed to you, [O Muhammad], and what was revealed before you? They wish to refer legislation to Taghut, while they were commanded to reject it; and Satan wishes to lead them far astray.
And when it is said to them, "Come to what Allah has revealed and to the Messenger," you see the hypocrites turning away from you in aversion.
So how [will it be] when disaster strikes them because of what their hands have put forth and then they come to you swearing by Allah, "We intended nothing but good conduct and accommodation."
Those are the ones of whom Allah knows what is in their hearts, so turn away from them but admonish them and speak to them a far-reaching word.

And We did not send any messenger except to be obeyed by permission of Allah. And if, when they wronged themselves, they had come to you, [O Muhammad], and asked forgiveness of Allah and the Messenger had asked forgiveness for them, they would have found Allah Accepting of repentance and Merciful.

So accept our repentance [tawba], O Allah, and let Your Prophet intercede for us in this, and elevate us by his station [manzila] with You and his right [haqq] upon You.

a.g: But no, by your Lord, they will not [truly] believe until they make you, [O Muhammad], judge concerning that over which they dispute among themselves and then find within themselves no discomfort from what you have judged and submit in [full, willing] submission.

And if We had decreed upon them, "Kill yourselves" or "Leave your homes," they would not have done it, except for a few of them. But if they had done what they were instructed, it would have been better for them and a firmer position [for them in faith].

Indeed, if you say: "What benefit is there in supplication [du'a], when the decree [qada'] cannot be turned back?" Then know that among the decrees is the repelling of affliction [bala'] through supplication. So supplication is a cause [sabab] for repelling affliction and for attracting mercy [rahma], just as the shield is a cause for repelling the arrow, and water is a cause for the emergence of plants from the earth. And just as the shield pushes against the arrow and they repel each other, so too do supplication and affliction contend with one another. And it is not a condition of affirming the decree [qada'] of God, the Exalted, that one should not carry a weapon, for He, the Exalted, has said: "Take your precaution." Nor is it that one should not water the earth after scattering the seed, saying, "If the decree [qada'] preceded it with growth, the seed will grow, and if it did not precede it, it will not grow." Rather, the linking of causes [asbab] to their effects [musabbabat] is the First Decree [al-qada' al-awwal], which is like the blinking of an eye, or even closer. And the arranging of the details of the effects according to the details of the causes, in gradual stages and by measure [taqdir], is the Ordainment [al-qadr]. And He who ordained [qaddara] the good ordained it with a cause, and He who ordained [qaddara] the evil ordained a cause for its repelling. So there is no contradiction between these matters for one whose insight [basira] has been opened.

a.g: And indeed, there is among you he who lingers behind; and if disaster strikes you, he says, "Allah has favored me in that I was not present with them."
But if bounty comes to you from Allah, he will surely say, as if there had never been between you and him any affection. "Oh, I wish I had been with them so I could have attained a great attainment."

So let those fight in the cause of Allah who sell the life of this world for the Hereafter. And he who fights in the cause of Allah and is killed or achieves victory - We will bestow upon him a great reward.

And what is [the matter] with you that you fight not in the cause of Allah and [for] the oppressed among men, women, and children who say, "Our Lord, take us out of this city of oppressive people and appoint for us from Yourself a protector and appoint for us from Yourself a helper?"
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Indeed, this indicates that whoever is afflicted with a land where sins [ma'asi] abound and good [khayr] is scarce has no excuse for remaining there. Rather, he should emigrate [yuhajir]. Allah the Exalted has said: "Was not the earth of Allah spacious [wasi'a] enough for you to emigrate therein?" If he is prevented from that by dependents or ties, he should not be content with his state, nor should his soul [nafs] be at peace with it. Rather, his heart [qalb] should be agitated by it, saying perpetually: "Our Lord, deliver us from this town whose people are wrongdoers [zalim]." This is because when injustice [zulm] becomes widespread, calamity descends and destroys all, encompassing the obedient. Allah the Exalted has said: "And fear a trial [fitna] which will not strike those who have wronged among you exclusively." Therefore, there is in none of the causes of deficiency in religion [din] any absolute contentment [rida] whatsoever, except in their attribution to the act of Allah the Exalted. As for them in themselves, there is no basis for contentment with them in any state.

a.g: Those who believe fight in the cause of Allah, and those who disbelieve fight in the cause of Taghut. So fight against the allies of Satan. Indeed, the plot of Satan has ever been weak.

Have you not seen those who were told, "Restrain your hands [from fighting] and establish prayer and give zakah"? But then when fighting was ordained for them, at once a party of them feared men as they fear Allah or with [even] greater fear. They said, "Our Lord, why have You decreed upon us fighting? If only You had postponed [it for] us for a short time." Say, The enjoyment of this world is little, and the Hereafter is better for he who fears Allah. And injustice will not be done to you, [even] as much as a thread [inside a date seed]."
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book4
Indeed, the ultimate reality is that asceticism [zuhd] is an expression of aversion to all the desires [huzuz] of the self [nafs]. Whenever one is averse to the desires of the self, he is averse to remaining in the world [dunya], and his hope [amal] is inevitably shortened. For he only desires to remain in order to enjoy, and he desires perpetual enjoyment through desiring permanence; for whoever desires a thing desires its permanence. And there is no meaning to the love of life except the love of the permanence of what exists or is possible in this life. So when he is averse to it, he does not desire it. And for this reason, when fighting was prescribed for them, "They said, 'Our Lord, why have You prescribed for us fighting? If only You had postponed it for us for a short time.'" So the Most High said: "Say, 'The enjoyment of the world is little.'" That is: You do not desire to remain except for the enjoyment of the world. Thus, at that point, the ascetics [zahidun] became manifest, and the condition of the hypocrites was unveiled. And the indication to defining the baseness of the world is in His saying, the Most High: "Say, 'The enjoyment of the world is little.'"

So what is [the matter] with those people that they can hardly understand any statement?

a.g: And they say, "[We pledge] obedience." But when they leave you, a group of them spend the night determining to do other than what you say. But Allah records what they plan by night. So leave them alone and rely upon Allah. And sufficient is Allah as Disposer of affairs.
Then do they not reflect upon the Qur'an? If it had been from [any] other than Allah, they would have found within it much contradiction.

And when there comes to them information about [public] security or fear, they spread it around. But if they had referred it back to the Messenger or to those of authority among them, then the ones who [can] draw correct conclusions from it would have known about it. And if not for the favor of Allah upon you and His mercy, you would have followed Satan, except for a few.

And Ibn 'Abbas also said: "If Pharaoh [Fir'awn] were to say something good to me, I would return it to him."

a.g: Allah - there is no deity except Him. He will surely assemble you for [account on] the Day of Resurrection, about which there is no doubt. And who is more truthful than Allah in statement.

What is [the matter] with you [that you are] two groups concerning the hypocrites, while Allah has made them fall back [into error and disbelief] for what they earned. Do you wish to guide those whom Allah has sent astray? And he whom Allah sends astray - never will you find for him a way [of guidance].

They wish you would disbelieve as they disbelieved so you would be alike. So do not take from among them allies until they emigrate for the cause of Allah. But if they turn away, then seize them and kill them wherever you find them and take not from among them any ally or helper.

Vol3 book5a
Know that there is no envy [hasad] except concerning a blessing [ni'mah]. So when God bestows a blessing upon your brother, you have two states concerning it: The first: That you dislike that blessing and desire its removal. This state is called envy [hasad]. So the definition of envy is: disliking the blessing and desiring its removal from the one upon whom it was bestowed. As for the first, it is forbidden in every circumstance, except for a blessing obtained by a wicked person or an unbeliever, which he uses to stir up strife [fitnah], corrupt relationships, and harm the truth. Then your dislike of it and your desire for its removal does not harm you, for you do not desire its removal insofar as it is a blessing, but rather insofar as it is an instrument of corruption. And if you were secure from his corruption, his blessing would not grieve you. The prohibition of envy is indicated by the narrations we have transmitted, and by the fact that this dislike is displeasure with God's decree in preferring some of His servants over others. There is no excuse or concession for that. And what sin is greater than your dislike of a Muslim's comfort when no harm from it reaches you? The Qur'an alludes to this in His saying: "If good befalls you, it grieves them, and if evil strikes you, they rejoice at it." This rejoicing is malicious glee [shamatah], and envy and malicious glee are concomitant. And the Almighty said: "Many of the People of the Book wish they could turn you back to disbelief after your belief, out of envy from themselves." So the Almighty informed that their love for the removal of the blessing of faith is envy. And the Almighty said: "They wish you would disbelieve as they have disbelieved, so you would be equal." And God the Almighty mentioned the envy of the brothers of Joseph, peace be upon him, and expressed what was in their hearts with His saying: "When they said, 'Joseph and his brother are more beloved to our father than we, while we are a clan. Indeed, our father is in clear error. Kill Joseph or cast him out to [another] land; the countenance of your father will [then] be only for you.'" So when they disliked their father's love for him and it distressed them, and they desired its removal from him, they hid him from him. And He said: "And they find within themselves no discomfort from what they were given" — meaning their breasts are not constricted by it and they are not grieved — so He praised them for the absence of envy. And He said, in the context of reproach: "Or do they envy people for what God has given them of His bounty?" And He said: "Mankind was one community" up to His saying: "Except those to whom it was given, after clear proofs had come to them, out of mutual envy." It is said in the interpretation: envy. And He said: "And they did not become divided until after knowledge had come to them, out of envy among themselves." So God sent down knowledge to unite them and bring them together in obedience to Him, and commanded them to unite through knowledge, but they envied one another and differed when each one of them desired to be alone with leadership and acceptance of speech, so they refuted one another. Ibn Abbas said: The Jews, before the Prophet ﷺ was sent, when they fought a people, would say: "We ask you by the Prophet you promised to send and by the Book you will reveal, that you grant us victory." And they would be granted victory. So when the Prophet ﷺ came from the descendants of Ishmael, peace be upon him, they recognized him and disbelieved in him after recognizing him. So the Almighty said: "And they used to entreat, before, for victory over those who disbelieved, but when there came to them that which they recognized, they disbelieved in it" up to His saying: "That they would disbelieve in what God has revealed, out of envy" — meaning envy. This is the ruling of envy concerning its prohibition.

a.g: Except for those who take refuge with a people between yourselves and whom is a treaty or those who come to you, their hearts strained at [the prospect of] fighting you or fighting their own people. And if Allah had willed, He could have given them power over you, and they would have fought you. So if they remove themselves from you and do not fight you and offer you peace, then Allah has not made for you a cause [for fighting] against them.

You will find others who wish to obtain security from you and [to] obtain security from their people. Every time they are returned to [the influence of] disbelief, they fall back into it. So if they do not withdraw from you or offer you peace or restrain their hands, then seize them and kill them wherever you overtake them. And those - We have made for you against them a clear authorization.

And never is it for a believer to kill a believer except by mistake. And whoever kills a believer by mistake - then the freeing of a believing slave and a compensation payment presented to the deceased's family [is required] unless they give [up their right as] charity. But if the deceased was from a people at war with you and he was a believer - then [only] the freeing of a believing slave; and if he was from a people with whom you have a treaty - then a compensation payment presented to his family and the freeing of a believing slave. And whoever does not find [one or cannot afford to buy one] - then [instead], a fast for two months consecutively, [seeking] acceptance of repentance from Allah. And Allah is ever Knowing and Wise.

But whoever kills a believer intentionally - his recompense is Hell, wherein he will abide eternally, and Allah has become angry with him and has cursed him and has prepared for him a great punishment.

O you who have believed, when you go forth [to fight] in the cause of Allah, investigate; and do not say to one who gives you [a greeting of] peace "You are not a believer," aspiring for the goods of worldly life; for with Allah are many acquisitions. You [yourselves] were like that before; then Allah conferred His favor upon you, so investigate. Indeed Allah is ever, with what you do, Acquainted.

j4 k08
Indeed, the looking [nazar] is in what lies before the servant in his day, that he may know his increase from his decrease through self-reckoning [muhasaba]. And Allah the Exalted has said: "O you who have believed, when you go forth in the path of Allah, then make clear [tabayyanu]."

a.g: Not equal are those believers remaining [at home] - other than the disabled - and the mujahideen, [who strive and fight] in the cause of Allah with their wealth and their lives. Allah has preferred the mujahideen through their wealth and their lives over those who remain [behind], by degrees. And to both Allah has promised the best [reward]. But Allah has preferred the mujahideen over those who remain [behind] with a great reward -
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j3 k01
Indeed, the second example: Know that the body [al-badan] is like a city, and the intellect [al-'aql]—I mean the perceiving faculty of the human—is like a king who administers it. Its perceiving powers, from the outward and inward senses [al-hawass al-dhahirah wa al-batinah], are like his soldiers and aides. Its limbs are like his subjects. And the soul that commands to evil [al-nafs al-ammarah bi al-su']—which is desire [al-shahwah] and anger [al-ghadab]—is like an enemy who contends with him for his kingdom and strives to destroy his subjects. Thus, his body becomes like a frontier post and a strategic pass, and his soul [nafs] is like one residing in it, stationed for vigilance [murabit]. If he strives [jahada] against his enemy, defeats him, and subdues him according to what he loves, his effect is praised. And when he returns to the Divine Presence [al-hadrah], as Allah, the Exalted, has said: "And those who strive [al-mujahidun] in the cause of Allah with their wealth and their selves, Allah has preferred the strivers [al-mujahidin] with their wealth and their selves over the sedentary by a degree." But if he neglects his strategic pass and disregards his subjects, his effect is blamed, and he will be taken to account by Allah, the Exalted. It will be said to him on the Day of Resurrection: "O wicked shepherd! You ate the flesh and drank the milk, yet you did not shelter the lost, nor did you mend the broken. Today I shall take vengeance upon you," as has come in the report. And to this striving [al-mujahadah] is the allusion in his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "We have returned from the lesser striving [al-jihad al-asghar] to the greater striving [al-jihad al-akbar]."

a.g: Degrees [of high position] from Him and forgiveness and mercy. And Allah is ever Forgiving and Merciful.

Indeed, those whom the angels take [in death] while wronging themselves - [the angels] will say, "In what [condition] were you?" They will say, "We were oppressed in the land." The angels will say, "Was not the earth of Allah spacious [enough] for you to emigrate therein?" For those, their refuge is Hell - and evil it is as a destination.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k04
Indeed, this indicates that whoever is afflicted with a city [balad] in which sins [ma'asi] abound and good [khayr] is scarce has no excuse for residing in it. Rather, he should emigrate [yuhajir]. Allah the Exalted has said: "Was not the earth of Allah spacious [wasi'a] that you could emigrate therein?" If he is prevented from that by dependents ['iyal] or ties ['alaqah], he should not be content with his state [hal], nor should his soul [nafs] be at peace with it. Rather, his heart [qalb] should be agitated by it, saying perpetually: "Our Lord, deliver us from this city whose people are wrongdoers [zalim]." This is because when injustice [zulm] becomes widespread, calamity descends and destroys all, encompassing the obedient [muti'in]. Allah the Exalted has said: "And fear a trial [fitnah] which will not strike those who have wronged among you exclusively." Therefore, there is in none of the causes of deficiency in religion [din] any absolute contentment [rida mutlaq] whatsoever, except in terms of attributing them to the act of Allah the Exalted. As for them in themselves, there is no basis for contentment with them in any state.

a.g: Except for the oppressed among men, women and children who cannot devise a plan nor are they directed to a way -
For those it is expected that Allah will pardon them, and Allah is ever Pardoning and Forgiving.

And whoever emigrates for the cause of Allah will find on the earth many [alternative] locations and abundance. And whoever leaves his home as an emigrant to Allah and His Messenger and then death overtakes him - his reward has already become incumbent upon Allah. And Allah is ever Forgiving and Merciful.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 7
Indeed, He ﷺ said: "Whoever leaves his home as a pilgrim [hajj] or a visitor ['umrah] and then dies, the reward of the pilgrim and the visitor will be recorded for him until the Day of Resurrection. And whoever dies in one of the two Sacred Sanctuaries [al-Haramayn] will not be presented [for judgment] and will not be held to account, and it will be said to him: 'Enter Paradise.'" And He ﷺ said: "The pilgrims [al-hujjaj] and the visitors [al-'ummar] are the delegation of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, and His visitors. If they ask Him, He gives them; if they seek His forgiveness, He forgives them; if they call upon Him, He answers them; and if they intercede, their intercession is accepted." And let him hope that if he does not reach it [the destination] and death [al-maniyyah] overtakes him on the way, he will meet Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, as a delegate to Him, since He, Majestic is His Majesty, said: "And whoever leaves his home emigrating [muhajiran] to Allah and His Messenger, and then death overtakes him, his reward has already fallen upon Allah."

a.g: And when you travel throughout the land, there is no blame upon you for shortening the prayer, [especially] if you fear that those who disbelieve may disrupt [or attack] you. Indeed, the disbelievers are ever to you a clear enemy.

And when you are among them and lead them in prayer, let a group of them stand [in prayer] with you and let them carry their arms. And when they have prostrated, let them be [in position] behind you and have the other group come forward which has not [yet] prayed and let them pray with you, taking precaution and carrying their arms. Those who disbelieve wish that you would neglect your weapons and your baggage so they could come down upon you in one [single] attack. But there is no blame upon you, if you are troubled by rain or are ill, for putting down your arms, but take precaution. Indeed, Allah has prepared for the disbelievers a humiliating punishment.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book 8a
Indeed, the Qur'an [al-Qur'an], from its beginning to its end, is a warning [tahdhir] from Satan [al-Shaytan]. So how [can it be otherwise] when He has commanded caution from the enemy, just as He commanded caution from the disbelievers, saying, the Most High: "And let them take their precaution and their arms." So if it is incumbent upon you, by the command of Allah, to be cautious of the disbelieving enemy whom you see, then it is more incumbent upon you to be cautious of an enemy who sees you and you do not see him. Therefore, being occupied with Allah [al-istighlal bi-Allah] does not mean turning away from that which Allah has warned against, and by this, the doctrine of the second group is invalidated in their assumption that this detracts from trust [al-tawakkul]. For taking up the shield and weapon, gathering the troops, and digging the trench did not detract from the trust [tawakkul] of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, so how could fearing that which Allah has warned against and being cautious of that which He has commanded caution from detract from trust [al-tawakkul]? And We have mentioned in the Book of Trust [Kitab al-Tawakkul] what clarifies the error of those who claim that the meaning of trust [al-tawakkul] is to completely abandon means [al-asbab]. And His saying, the Most High: "And prepare against them whatever you are able of power and of steeds of war" does not contradict compliance with trust [al-tawakkul], as long as the heart [al-qalb] believes that the One who harms and benefits, the One who gives life and causes death, is Allah, the Most High. Likewise, one is cautious of Satan [al-Shaytan] while believing that the One who guides and leads astray is Allah, and sees the means [al-asbab] as subjugated intermediaries—as We have mentioned in the Book of Trust [Kitab al-Tawakkul].

a.g: And when you have completed the prayer, remember Allah standing, sitting, or [lying] on your sides. But when you become secure, re-establish [regular] prayer. Indeed, prayer has been decreed upon the believers a decree of specified times.

(4:103) Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: "That is, by night and by day, on land and at sea, in travel and in residence, in wealth and in poverty, in sickness and in health, in secret and in public."

a.g: And do not weaken in pursuit of the enemy. If you should be suffering - so are they suffering as you are suffering, but you expect from Allah that which they expect not. And Allah is ever Knowing and Wise.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book2
And it is not fitting that we say the one who turns away from the world [dunya] is pained by patience [sabr] concerning it, for the one who inclines towards it is also pained by patience concerning it, and by guarding it, and by acquiring it, and by repelling thieves from it. And the pain of the one who turns away leads to pleasure in the Hereafter [akhirah], and the pain of the one who inclines leads to pain in the Hereafter. So let the one who turns away from the world recite upon himself the saying of the Almighty: "And do not weaken in pursuit of the enemy. If you should be suffering - so indeed they are suffering as you are suffering, but you hope from Allah that for which they do not hope." Therefore, the path of gratitude [shukr] has only been blocked for creation due to their ignorance of the varieties of blessings [ni'am], the apparent and the hidden, the specific and the general.

a.g: Indeed, We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], the Book in truth so you may judge between the people by that which Allah has shown you. And do not be for the deceitful an advocate.
And seek forgiveness of Allah. Indeed, Allah is ever Forgiving and Merciful.
And do not argue on behalf of those who deceive themselves. Indeed, Allah loves not one who is a habitually sinful deceiver.

They conceal [their evil intentions and deeds] from the people, but they cannot conceal [them] from Allah, and He is with them [in His knowledge] when they spend the night in such as He does not accept of speech. And ever is Allah, of what they do, encompassing.
Here you are - those who argue on their behalf in [this] worldly life - but who will argue with Allah for them on the Day of Resurrection, or who will [then] be their representative?
And whoever does a wrong or wrongs himself but then seeks forgiveness of Allah will find Allah Forgiving and Merciful.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 9
Indeed, and He, the Exalted, says: "And whoever does an evil [sū’an] or wrongs his own soul [nafsahu] then seeks forgiveness from Allah, he will find Allah Forgiving, Merciful." And we seek forgiveness from Allah, the Exalted, for every slip of the foot or transgression of the pen that occurred in this book of ours and in all our other books. And we seek His forgiveness for our words which our deeds do not match. And we seek His forgiveness for what we claimed and displayed of knowledge [‘ilm] and insight [baṣīrah] into the religion of Allah, the Exalted, while falling short in it. And we seek His forgiveness for every knowledge [‘ilm] and action we intended by it His Noble Countenance, then something else became mixed with it. And we seek His forgiveness for every promise we made to ourselves, then fell short in fulfilling it. And we seek His forgiveness for every blessing [ni‘mah] He bestowed upon us, then we used it in disobedience to Him. And we seek His forgiveness for every explicit statement and allusion to the deficiency of one deficient and the shortcoming of one falling short, which we ourselves were characterized by. And we seek His forgiveness for every fleeting thought that called us to affectation and pretense, to adorn ourselves for people in a book we penned, or speech we composed, or knowledge [‘ilm] we imparted or received. And we hope, after seeking forgiveness for all of that in its entirety—for us and for whoever reads this book of ours, or writes it, or hears it—that we may be honored with forgiveness [maghfirah] and mercy [raḥmah] and pardon for all misdeeds, outward and inward. For generosity is vast, and mercy [raḥmah] is expansive, and bounty upon all varieties of creation is overflowing. And we are a creation [khalq] from among the creations of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic; we have no means to Him except His favor and His generosity.

a.g: And whoever commits a sin only earns it against himself. And Allah is ever Knowing and Wise.
But whoever earns an offense or a sin and then blames it on an innocent [person] has taken upon himself a slander and manifest sin.

And if it was not for the favor of Allah upon you, [O Muhammad], and His mercy, a group of them would have determined to mislead you. But they do not mislead except themselves, and they will not harm you at all. And Allah has revealed to you the Book and wisdom and has taught you that which you did not know. And ever has the favor of Allah upon you been great.

Vol1 book 4
Indeed, the greatest blessing [ni'mah] of Allah upon His servants is knowledge ['ilm] and the unveiling [kashf] of the Truth [al-Haqq]. And faith [iman] is an expression of a type of unveiling [kashf] and knowledge ['ilm]. And for that reason, the Most High said, bestowing favor upon His servant: "And great was the grace [fadl] of Allah upon you." And He intended by it knowledge ['ilm]. And the Most High said: "So ask the people of the Remembrance [Dhikr] if you do not know." And the Most High said: "Indeed, upon Us is the guidance [al-huda]." And He said: "Then indeed, upon Us is its explanation [bayan]." And He said: "And upon Allah is the direction of the path [sabil]."

And the Most High said: "So ask the people of the Remembrance [Dhikr] if you do not know." And the Most High said: "Indeed, upon Us is the guidance [al-huda]." And He said: "Then indeed, upon Us is its explanation [bayan]." And He said: "And upon Allah is the direction of the path [sabil]."

Indeed, Allah does not forgive association with Him, but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills. And he who associates others with Allah has certainly gone far astray.
They call upon instead of Him none but female [deities], and they [actually] call upon none but a rebellious Satan.
Whom Allah has cursed. For he had said, "I will surely take from among Your servants a specific portion.

And I will mislead them, and I will arouse in them [sinful] desires, and I will command them so they will slit the ears of cattle, and I will command them so they will change the creation of Allah." And whoever takes Satan as an ally instead of Allah has certainly sustained a clear loss.

a.g: Satan promises them and arouses desire in them. But Satan does not promise them except delusion.
The refuge of those will be Hell, and they will not find from it an escape.

But the ones who believe and do righteous deeds - We will admit them to gardens beneath which rivers flow, wherein they will abide forever. [It is] the promise of Allah, [which is] truth, and who is more truthful than Allah in statement.

Paradise is not [obtained] by your wishful thinking nor by that of the People of the Scripture. Whoever does a wrong will be recompensed for it, and he will not find besides Allah a protector or a helper.

And they request from you, [O Muhammad], a [legal] ruling concerning women. And whatever you do of good - indeed, Allah is ever Knowing of it.

And if a woman fears from her husband contempt or evasion, there is no sin upon them if they make terms of settlement between them - and settlement is best. And present in [human] souls is stinginess. But if you do good and fear Allah - then indeed Allah is ever, with what you do, Acquainted.

And you will never be able to be equal [in feeling] between wives, even if you should strive [to do so]. So do not incline completely [toward one] and leave another hanging. And if you amend [your affairs] and fear Allah - then indeed, Allah is ever Forgiving and Merciful.

O you who have believed, be persistently standing firm in justice, witnesses for Allah, even if it be against yourselves or parents and relatives. Indeed, Abu Bakr stood before the people as an orator when the people had exhausted their tears with a sermon, most of which was prayers upon the Prophet ﷺ. So he praised Allah and extolled Him in every state and said: I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, He fulfilled His promise [wa'd] and aided His servant ['abd] and defeated the confederates alone, so to Allah alone is all praise. And I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and His Messenger and the seal of His prophets. And I bear witness that the Book is as He legislated, and the religion [din] is as He legislated, and the tradition [hadith] is as it was narrated, and the statement is as it was said, and that Allah is the Manifest Truth. O Allah, send prayers upon Muhammad, Your servant and Your Messenger and Your Prophet and Your beloved and Your trustee and Your chosen one and Your elect, with the best of what You have sent as prayers upon any of Your creation. O Allah, and make Your prayers and Your safekeeping and Your mercy upon the master of the messengers and the seal of the prophets and the Imam of the God-conscious [muttaqin], Muhammad, the leader of good and the Imam of good and the Messenger of mercy. O Allah, bring near his proximity [zulfah] and magnify his proof [burhan] and honor his station [maqam] and resurrect him to a praiseworthy station [maqam mahmud] which the first and the last will envy. And benefit us by his praiseworthy station on the Day of Resurrection, and grant him succession among us in the world [dunya] and the Hereafter, and grant him the highest degree and the means of nearness in Paradise. O Allah, send prayers upon Muhammad and upon the family of Muhammad, and bless Muhammad and upon the family of Muhammad as You sent prayers and blessed Ibrahim, indeed You are Praiseworthy, Glorious. O people, indeed whoever was worshipping Muhammad, then Muhammad has died. And whoever was worshipping Allah, then Allah is Alive, He does not die. And indeed Allah has presented to you in His command, so do not call upon Him in panic, for Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, has chosen for His Prophet ﷺ what is with Him over what is with you, and took him to His reward, and left among you His Book and the tradition [sunnah] of His Prophet ﷺ. And treat Satan with good, you will incapacitate him, and do not seek respite from him, lest he overtake you and tempt you.

a.g: O you who have believed, believe in Allah and His Messenger and the Book that He sent down upon His Messenger and the Scripture which He sent down before. And whoever disbelieves in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, and the Last Day has certainly gone far astray.
Indeed, those who have believed then disbelieved, then believed, then disbelieved, and then increased in disbelief - never will Allah forgive them, nor will He guide them to a way.
Give tidings to the hypocrites that there is for them a painful punishment -
Those who take disbelievers as allies instead of the believers. Do they seek with them honor [through power]? But indeed, honor belongs to Allah entirely.

And it has already come down to you in the Book that when you hear the verses of Allah [recited], they are denied [by them] and ridiculed; so do not sit with them until they enter into another conversation. Indeed, you would then be like them. Indeed Allah will gather the hypocrites and disbelievers in Hell all together -

Vol1 book 6
Indeed, the third affliction is plunging into falsehood [al-batil], and it is speech concerning sins, such as recounting the states of women, gatherings of wine, the stations of the dissolute, the luxuries of the wealthy, the tyranny of kings and their blameworthy customs and their detestable conditions. For all of that is from what it is not permissible to plunge into, and it is forbidden. Most people sit together for amusement through conversation, and their speech does not go beyond jesting with the honor of people or plunging into falsehood [al-batil]. The types of falsehood [al-batil] cannot be enumerated due to their multitude and variety; therefore, there is no deliverance from them except by restricting oneself to what is of concern from the important matters of religion [din] and the world [dunya]. And the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "The greatest of people in sins on the Day of Resurrection will be the one who plunges most into falsehood [al-batil]." And to this is the allusion by His saying, the Exalted: "And we used to plunge with those who plunge." And by His saying, the Exalted: "Then do not sit with them until they plunge into a discourse other than it; indeed, you would then be like them." And Salman said: "The greatest of people in sins on the Day of Resurrection will be the one who speaks most in disobedience to Allah." So this is plunging into falsehood [al-batil], and it is beyond what will come of backbiting, tale-bearing, obscenity, and others. Rather, it is plunging into the mention of prohibitions whose occurrence has preceded, or contemplating to find a way to them, without a religious need to mention them. And there also enters into it plunging into recounting innovations and corrupt doctrines, and recounting what occurred of the fighting among the Companions in a manner that suggests disparagement of some of them. And all of that is falsehood [al-batil], and plunging into it is plunging into falsehood [al-batil]. We ask Allah for good assistance through His gentleness and generosity.

a.g: Those who wait [and watch] you. Then if you gain a victory from Allah, they say, "Were we not with you?" But if the disbelievers have a success, they say [to them], "Did we not gain the advantage over you, but we protected you from the believers?" Allah will judge between [all of] you on the Day of Resurrection, and never will Allah give the disbelievers over the believers a way [to overcome them].
