j2 k09
Indeed, the sinner [fāsiq]—if he is overpowered by action, he has already been overpowered by the proof [ḥujja], for it is directed at him that it be said to him: 'You did not precede him, so natural dispositions [ṭabā'i'] recoil from overpowering him by action while he is already overpowered by the proof.' And that does not remove the action from being truth [ḥaqq], just as one who repels the wrongdoer [ẓālim] from individual Muslims yet neglects his own father who is wronged among them—natural dispositions recoil from him, yet his repelling of the wrongdoer from the Muslim does not cease to be truth. From this it emerges that the sinner is not subject to commanding right [ḥisba] through admonition [wa'ẓ] upon one who knows his sinfulness, because he will not take admonition. And since that is not incumbent upon him, and it is known that it leads to prolonging the tongue in disparaging him through rebuke, we say: he does not have that right either. Thus, the discussion returns to the fact that one of the two types of commanding right—which is admonition—has been invalidated by sinfulness [fisq], and uprightness [ʿadāla] has been stipulated for it. As for coercive commanding right [ḥisba qahriyya], uprightness is not stipulated in it. So there is no blame upon the sinner in spilling wines, breaking instruments of diversion, and other such things if he is able. And this is the utmost fairness and unveiling in the matter. As for the verses they used as proof, it is a rebuke of them for their abandoning of the recognized good [maʿrūf], not for their commanding it. But their commanding it indicates the strength of their knowledge [ʿilm], and the punishment of the knower [ʿālim] is more severe because he has no excuse with the strength of his knowledge. And His saying, exalted is He: "Why do you say what you do not do?"—the intent is the false promise. And His saying, mighty and majestic is He: "And you forget yourselves"—it is a rebuke for their forgetting themselves, not for their commanding others. But the mention of commanding others is used as evidence for their knowledge and to confirm the proof against them. And His saying: "O son of Maryam, admonish yourself..."—the ḥadīth is concerning commanding right through admonition, and we have conceded that the admonition of the sinner is of null benefit with one who knows his sinfulness. Then His saying: "So be ashamed before Me"—it does not indicate the prohibition of admonishing others. Rather, its meaning is: be ashamed before Me, so do not abandon the more important and occupy yourself with the less important, just as it is said: 'Preserve your father, then your neighbor; otherwise, be ashamed.' If it is said: 'Then let it be permissible for the protected unbeliever [kāfir dhimmī] to command right upon the Muslim if he sees him fornicating, because his saying "Do not fornicate" is truth in itself, so it is impossible for it to be forbidden for him; rather, it should be permissible or obligatory.' We say: The unbeliever, if he prevents the Muslim by his action, that is an act of domination [tasalluṭ] over him, so he is prevented because it is domination, and "Allah has not given the unbelievers over the believers any way." As for his mere saying "Do not fornicate," it is not forbidden for him inasmuch as it is a prohibition of fornication, but inasmuch as it is a display of the authority [dāla] of passing judgment [iḥtikām] upon the Muslim, and in it is humiliation [idhlāl] for the one judged upon. And the sinner deserves humiliation, but not from the unbeliever who is more deserving of lowliness than he. This is the aspect of our preventing him from commanding right. Otherwise, we do not say that the unbeliever is punished because of his saying "Do not fornicate" inasmuch as he prohibited; rather, we say that if he does not say "Do not fornicate," he is punished for it—if we consider addressing the unbeliever with the branches of the religion, and there is consideration in that which we have thoroughly covered in the legal discussions, and it is not suitable for our purpose now. The fourth condition: that he be authorized from the side of the Imam and the ruler. Some have stipulated this condition and have not affirmed commanding right for the individuals among the subjects [raʿiyya]. And this stipulation is invalid, for the verses and reports we have cited indicate that whoever sees a wrong [munkar] and remains silent upon it has disobeyed, since forbidding it is obligatory wherever he sees it and however he sees it, in a general sense. So specifying it with the condition of delegation [tafwīḍ] from the Imam is arbitrary, having no basis. And it is astonishing that the Rāfiḍah increased upon this, saying: 'Commanding right is not permissible unless the infallible Imam emerges—and he is the rightful Imam according to them.' These are of the lowest rank to even be spoken to. Rather, the answer to them is to say to them: 'When you come to the judiciary seeking your rights in your blood and your wealth, our aiding you is commanding right, and extracting your rights from the hands of those who wronged you is forbidding wrong, and your seeking your right is from the totality of the recognized good. And is this not the time for forbidding wrong and seeking rights, because the rightful Imam has not yet emerged?' If it is said: 'In commanding right is the affirmation of sovereignty [sulṭāna] and authority [wilāya] and passing judgment upon the one judged. Therefore, it was not affirmed for the unbeliever over the Muslim, even though it is truth in itself. So it should not be affirmed for individuals among the subjects except by delegation from the ruler and the one in authority.' We say: As for the unbeliever, he is prevented because of what it contains of domination and the honor of passing judgment, and the unbeliever is lowly, so he does not deserve to attain the honor of judging over the Muslim. As for the individuals among the Muslims, they deserve this honor by religion [dīn] and knowledge [maʿrifa]. And what it contains of the honor of sovereignty and passing judgment does not necessitate delegation, like the honor of teaching and making known, for there is no disagreement that making known the prohibition and obligation to one who is ignorant and proceeding towards wrong out of ignorance...

Indeed, the second pillar: that which is shown off with, and it is acts of obedience [ta'at], and this divides into showing off with the foundations of worship and into showing off with its attributes. The first division, and it is the most severe: showing off with the foundations, and it is upon three degrees. "The first": showing off with the foundation of faith [iman], and this is the most severe of the doors of showing off, and its companion is eternally in the Fire, and he is the one who displays the two statements of testimony [shahada] while his inner being is laden with denial, but he shows off with the outward appearance of Islam, and he is the one whom Allah, the Exalted, mentioned in His Book in various places, like His saying, the Mighty and Majestic: "When the hypocrites come to you, they say, 'We testify that you are the Messenger of Allah.' And Allah knows that you are His Messenger, and Allah testifies that the hypocrites are liars" — meaning in their indication by their statement of their inner secrets. And He, the Exalted, said: "And among the people is he whose speech pleases you in the life of this world [al-dunya], and he calls Allah to witness as to what is in his heart, yet he is the fiercest of opponents. And when he turns away, he strives throughout the land to cause corruption therein..." the verse. And He, the Exalted, said: "And when they meet you, they say, 'We believe,' but when they are alone, they bite their fingertips at you in rage." And He, the Exalted, said: "They show [the people] and do not remember Allah except a little, wavering between that..." And the verses concerning them are many.

"The first": showing off with the foundation of faith [iman], and this is the most severe of the doors of showing off, and its companion is eternally in the Fire, and he is the one who displays the two statements of testimony [shahada] while his inner being is laden with denial, but he shows off with the outward appearance of Islam, and he is the one whom Allah, the Exalted, mentioned in His Book in various places, like His saying, the Mighty and Majestic: "When the hypocrites come to you, they say, 'We testify that you are the Messenger of Allah.' And Allah knows that you are His Messenger, and Allah testifies that the hypocrites are liars" — meaning in their indication by their statement of their inner secrets. And He, the Exalted, said: "And among the people is he whose speech pleases you in the life of this world [al-dunya], and he calls Allah to witness as to what is in his heart, yet he is the fiercest of opponents. And when he turns away, he strives throughout the land to cause corruption therein..." the verse. And He, the Exalted, said: "And when they meet you, they say, 'We believe,' but when they are alone, they bite their fingertips at you in rage." And He, the Exalted, said: "They show [the people] and do not remember Allah except a little, wavering between that..." And the verses concerning them are many.

a.g: Wavering between them, [belonging] neither to the believers nor to the disbelievers. And whoever Allah leaves astray - never will you find for him a way.
O you who have believed, do not take the disbelievers as allies instead of the believers. Do you wish to give Allah against yourselves a clear case?
Indeed, the hypocrites will be in the lowest depths of the Fire - and never will you find for them a helper -

Allah, the Exalted, said: "And they were not commanded except to worship Allah, making their religion [din] pure for Him." And He said: "Indeed, the pure religion [din] is for Allah." And He, the Exalted, said: "Except those who repent and reform and hold fast to Allah and make their religion [din] pure for Allah." And He, the Exalted, said: "So whoever hopes for the meeting with his Lord, let him do righteous work and not associate in the worship of his Lord anyone." This was revealed concerning one who acts for Allah but loves to be praised for it. And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Three things against which the heart [qalb] of a believing man is not sealed: sincerity [ikhlas] of action for Allah." And from Mus'ab ibn Sa'd, from his father, who said: My father thought he had virtue over those beneath him among the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah, Mighty and Majestic, grants victory to this nation through its weak ones, their supplication, and their sincerity [ikhlas]." And from Al-Hasan, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Allah, the Exalted, says: 'Sincerity [ikhlas] is a secret from My secrets; I have deposited it in the heart [qalb] of whom I love from My servants.'" And 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah honor his face, said: "Do not concern yourselves with the smallness of the action, but concern yourselves with its acceptance. For the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Mu'adh ibn Jabal: 'Make the action sincere [ikhlas], and a little of it will suffice you.'" And he, peace be upon him, said: "There is no servant who makes his action sincere [ikhlas] for Allah for forty days except that the springs of wisdom [hikma] will appear from his heart [qalb] upon his tongue." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The first to be questioned on the Day of Resurrection are three: A man whom Allah granted knowledge ['ilm]. Allah will say: 'What did you do with what you knew?' He will say: 'My Lord, I would stand in prayer at night and by day.' Allah will say: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say: 'You have lied. Rather, you wanted it to be said: So-and-so is a scholar. Behold, it was said.' And a man whom Allah granted wealth. Allah will say: 'I have bestowed favor upon you, so what did you do?' He will say: 'My Lord, I would give charity with it at night and by day.' Allah will say: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say: 'You have lied. Rather, you wanted it to be said: So-and-so is generous. Behold, it was said.' And a man who was killed in the path of Allah. Allah will say: 'What did you do?' a.g: What would Allah do with your punishment if you are grateful and believe? And ever is Allah Appreciative and Knowing.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book2
Know that God the Exalted has coupled gratitude [shukr] with remembrance [dhikr] in His Book, even though He has said: "And the remembrance of God is greater." Indeed, He the Exalted said: "So remember Me; I will remember you. And be grateful to Me and do not deny Me." And He the Exalted said: "What would God do with your punishment if you are grateful and believe?" And He the Exalted said: "And We will reward the grateful." And He, Mighty and Majestic, said, informing about the accursed Iblis: "I will surely sit in ambush for them on Your straight path." It is said this is the path of gratitude [shukr]. And due to the exalted rank of gratitude [shukr], the accursed one assailed creation, saying: "And You will not find most of them grateful." And He the Exalted said: "And few of My servants are grateful." And God the Exalted has decreed increase with gratitude [shukr] without exception, for He the Exalted said: "If you are grateful, I will surely increase you."

a.g: Allah does not like the public mention of evil except by one who has been wronged. And ever is Allah Hearing and Knowing.
If [instead] you show [some] good or conceal it or pardon an offense - indeed, Allah is ever Pardoning and Competent.

Indeed, those who disbelieve in Allah and His messengers and wish to discriminate between Allah and His messengers and say, "We believe in some and disbelieve in others," and wish to adopt a way in between -
Those are the disbelievers, truly. And We have prepared for the disbelievers a humiliating punishment.
But they who believe in Allah and His messengers and do not discriminate between any of them - to those He is going to give their rewards. And ever is Allah Forgiving and Merciful.

The People of the Scripture ask you to bring down to them a book from the heaven. But they had asked of Moses [even] greater than that and said, "Show us Allah outright," so the thunderbolt struck them for their wrongdoing. Then they took the calf [for worship] after clear evidences had come to them, and We pardoned that. And We gave Moses a clear authority.

And We raised over them the mount for [refusal of] their covenant; and We said to them, "Enter the gate bowing humbly", and We said to them, "Do not transgress on the sabbath", and We took from them a solemn covenant.

And [We cursed them] for their breaking of the covenant and their disbelief in the signs of Allah and their killing of the prophets without right and their saying, "Our hearts are wrapped". Rather, Allah has sealed them because of their disbelief, so they believe not, except for a few.
And [We cursed them] for their disbelief and their saying against Mary a great slander,

And [for] their saying, "Indeed, we have killed the Messiah, Jesus, the son of Mary, the messenger of Allah." And they did not kill him, nor did they crucify him; but [another] was made to resemble him to them. And indeed, those who differ over it are in doubt about it. They have no knowledge of it except the following of assumption. And they did not kill him, for certain.
Rather, Allah raised him to Himself. And ever is Allah Exalted in Might and Wise.
And there is none from the People of the Scripture but that he will surely believe in Jesus before his death. And on the Day of Resurrection he will be against them a witness.
For wrongdoing on the part of the Jews, We made unlawful for them [certain] good foods which had been lawful to them, and for their averting from the way of Allah many [people],
And [for] their taking of usury while they had been forbidden from it, and their consuming of the people's wealth unjustly. And we have prepared for the disbelievers among them a painful punishment.

But those firm in knowledge among them and the believers believe in what has been revealed to you, [O Muhammad], and what was revealed before you. And the establishers of prayer [especially] and the givers of zakah and the believers in Allah and the Last Day - those We will give a great reward.

Indeed, We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], as We revealed to Noah and the prophets after him. And we revealed to Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, the Descendants, Jesus, Job, Jonah, Aaron, and Solomon, and to David We gave the book [of Psalms].
And [We sent] messengers about whom We have related [their stories] to you before and messengers about whom We have not related to you. And Allah spoke to Moses with [direct] speech.
[We sent] messengers as bringers of good tidings and warners so that mankind will have no argument against Allah after the messengers. And ever is Allah Exalted in Might and Wise.
But Allah bears witness to that which He has revealed to you. He has sent it down with His knowledge, and the angels bear witness [as well]. And sufficient is Allah as Witness.
Indeed, those who disbelieve and avert [people] from the way of Allah have certainly gone far astray.
Indeed, those who disbelieve and commit wrong [or injustice] - never will Allah forgive them, nor will He guide them to a path.
Except the path of Hell; they will abide therein forever. And that, for Allah, is [always] easy.

O Mankind, the Messenger has come to you with the truth from your Lord, so believe; it is better for you. But if you disbelieve - then indeed, to Allah belongs whatever is in the heavens and earth. And ever is Allah Knowing and Wise.

O People of the Scripture, do not commit excess in your religion or say about Allah except the truth. The Messiah, Jesus, the son of Mary, was but a messenger of Allah and His word which He directed to Mary and a soul [created at a command] from Him. So believe in Allah and His messengers. And do not say, "Three"; desist - it is better for you. Indeed, Allah is but one God. Exalted is He above having a son. To Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. And sufficient is Allah as Disposer of affairs.
Never would the Messiah disdain to be a servant of Allah, nor would the angels near [to Him]. And whoever disdains His worship and is arrogant - He will gather them to Himself all together.

And as for those who believed and did righteous deeds, He will give them in full their rewards and grant them extra from His bounty. But as for those who disdained and were arrogant, He will punish them with a painful punishment, and they will not find for themselves besides Allah any protector or helper.
O mankind, there has come to you a conclusive proof from your Lord, and We have sent down to you a clear light.
So those who believe in Allah and hold fast to Him - He will admit them to mercy from Himself and bounty and guide them to Himself on a straight path.

They request from you a [legal] ruling. Say, "Allah gives you a ruling concerning one having neither descendants nor ascendants [as heirs]." If a man dies, leaving no child but [only] a sister, she will have half of what he left. And he inherits from her if she [dies and] has no child. But if there are two sisters [or more], they will have two-thirds of what he left. If there are both brothers and sisters, the male will have the share of two females. Allah makes clear to you [His law], lest you go astray. And Allah is Knowing of all things.
